title: Cumulative Illness Rating Scale-Geriatric (CIRS-G)
description: Quantifies burden of illness in elderly patients by systematically rating the severity of medical conditions across multiple organ systems. The CIRS-G is considered potentially more accurate than the Charlson Comorbidity Index for geriatric patients and provides a comprehensive assessment of overall health status.

result.name: cirs_g_assessment
result.description: Comprehensive CIRS-G assessment including total score, severity indices, and comorbidity analysis

ranges.interpretation: Low overall illness burden with minimal impact on health status. Patients typically have good functional capacity and prognosis.
Mild to moderate illness burden. Some health conditions present but generally well-managed with good overall functional status.
Moderate illness burden with multiple health conditions or more severe single conditions. May impact daily activities and require comprehensive care.
High illness burden with multiple severe conditions or very severe single conditions. Significant impact on function and quality of life.
Very high illness burden with multiple severe conditions. May indicate poor prognosis and need for intensive medical management or palliative care.

clinical_applications: Predicting hospital outcomes and length of stay
references: Miller MD, Paradis CF, Houck PR, et al. Rating chronic medical illness burden in geropsychiatric practice and research: application of the Cumulative Illness Rating Scale. Psychiatry Res. 1992;41(3):237-248. doi: 10.1016/0165-1781(92)90005-n.
Linn BS, Linn MW, Gurel L. Cumulative illness rating scale. J Am Geriatr Soc. 1968;16(5):622-626. doi: 10.1111/j.1532-5415.1968.tb02103.x.
Hudon C, Fortin M, Vanasse A. Cumulative Illness Rating Scale was a reliable and valid index in a family practice context. J Clin Epidemiol. 2005;58(6):603-608. doi: 10.1016/j.jclinepi.2004.10.017.

Salvi F, Miller MD, Grilli A, et al. A manual of guidelines to score the modified cumulative illness rating scale and its validation in acute hospitalized elderly patients. J Am Geriatr Soc. 2008;56(10):1926-1931. doi: 10.1111/j.1532-5415.2008.01935.x.
formula: Total Score = Sum of all 13 organ system scores (0-52); Severity Index = Total Score / Number of categories with scores > 0; Comorbidity Index = Number of categories with scores ≥ 3
notes: Scores range from 0-52 (13 categories × 4 maximum points each)
Higher scores indicate greater illness burden
Consider both the total score and the number of affected organ systems
The CIRS-G may be more accurate than Charlson Comorbidity Index for geriatric patients
Useful for predicting hospital outcomes including mortality and length of stay
Should be completed by trained healthcare professionals familiar with the patient's medical history
Score can be used to track changes in illness burden over time
